marketNews.title: RI Proposal for Negotiations on U.S. Tariffs
marketNews.content:
Indonesia’s government on Tuesday (8 April) announced its response to the reciprocal tariff imposed by the United States. In principle, President Prabowo Subianto said Indonesia will pursue negotiations with the United States, including revitalising the trade and investment agreement that has not been updated since 1996. The government is formulating several policy measures to be offered as a negotiation package with the United States, including:

- **Deregulation of Non-Tariff Measures (NTMs)** – Finance Minister Sri Mulyani said the NTM option was chosen after reflecting on the United States’ rejection of Vietnam’s proposal to offer a 0% U.S. import tariff. The U.S. rejection was because the United States also considers non-tariff barriers in its reciprocal-tariff negotiations. The NTMs proposed by the Indonesian government include: 1) relaxation of the domestic content (TKDN) component level in the technology, information and communications (ICT) sector from the United States; 2) evaluation of import procedures, such as simplification/removal of import quotas/technical licences; and 3) acceleration of halal certification. Currently, Indonesia applies a minimum 25% TKDN requirement, with several ICT products required to have a minimum 35% TKDN.
- **Increase of Imports from the United States** – The increase aims to balance Indonesia’s trade balance with the United States. Indonesia recorded a US trade surplus of USD 19.3 billion in 2024, the fourth-largest in Southeast Asia. Going forward, the government plans to increase imports from the United States, covering agricultural products such as soybeans and wheat, engineering equipment, and oil-and-gas products such as LPG. Currently, the United States supplies 89% of Indonesia’s soybean imports, 5% of wheat, 5% of engineering equipment, and 53% of LPG.
- **Fiscal Incentives** – A number of incentives are being prepared to facilitate business, including for U.S. investors. The fiscal incentives include acceleration and simplification of various tax processes (such as audits and restitutions) and adjustments to various rates (import corporate income tax, import duties on U.S. products, and export duties on palm oil).

Co-ordinator of Economic Affairs Minister Airlangga Hartarto said the government has sent a letter to the United States government regarding this negotiation package.

marketNews.title: Key Takeaway
marketNews.content: In general, the relaxation of business rules through deregulation of TKDN requirements and/or easing of import provisions could increase competition for domestic manufacturers, although it may benefit consumers. At the same time, adjustments to various tariffs and duties could reduce potential state revenue. These risks could be offset if Indonesia secures a negotiation agreement that smooths the path for expanding export market share to the United States (trade diversion). Investors should watch the dynamic negotiations, avoid panic selling, and stay invested if the fundamentals of their holdings are sound. History shows markets can recover from crises such as 2008 and 2020. A diversified portfolio across asset classes can help mitigate volatility; short-term government bonds (e.g., PBS003, ST014-T2) or money-market funds are also options.

marketNews.title: U.S. Raises Tariffs on China to 104% Amid Trade Tensions
marketNews.content: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday (8 April) decided to raise the import tariff on China by an additional 50 percentage points, bringing the total U.S. tariff on Chinese goods to 104%, effective early Wednesday (9 April). The move follows China’s retaliatory reciprocal tariff. Previously, China faced a 20% tariff and a 34% reciprocal tariff. In response, China on Wednesday (9 April) announced an increase of its tariff on U.S. imports from 34% to 84% effective 10 April, and said it will seek recourse at the World Trade Organization.

marketNews.title: Rupiah Hits All-Time Low as Trade-War Pressures Intensify
marketNews.content: The Indonesian rupiah fell 0.5% to 16,957 per U.S. dollar in intraday trading on Wednesday (9 April), marking an all-time low. Senior Deputy Governor of Bank Indonesia, Destry Damayanti said the central bank will act decisively to maintain rupiah stability by intervening in the spot market, the domestic non-deliverable forwards market, and the bond market. She explained that the regional currency weakness is driven by the escalation of the global trade war, especially the United States’ decision to raise the tariff on Chinese imports to 104%.

marketNews.title: Indonesia’s 3Q 2025 Fiscal Deficit and Budget Execution
marketNews.content: The Ministry of Finance reported that the 2025 first-quarter (3M25) fiscal deficit reached 104.2 trillion rupiah, or 0.43% of GDP (versus a 0.04% surplus in March 2024; the 2025 target is a 2.53% deficit). State revenue realized 516.1 trillion rupiah, 17.2% of the 2025 target, down 16.8% YoY. State spending rose 1.4% YoY to 620.3 trillion rupiah, 17.1% of target. The primary balance narrowed to 17.5 trillion rupiah (versus a 122.1 trillion surplus in March 2024; the 2025 target is a 63.3 trillion deficit). Budget financing reached 250 trillion rupiah, 40.6% of the 2025 target (versus 83.97 trillion in March 2024).

marketNews.title: Trump Signals Openness to Trade Deal with Multiple Countries
marketNews.content: U.S. President Donald Trump signaled on Tuesday (8 April) that the United States is open to reaching an agreement that could reduce or eliminate the higher reciprocal tariff for 57 countries. The statement came amid negotiations by Asian and European leaders with the U.S. government, although Trump continued to implement the higher reciprocal tariff for the 57 countries as of early Wednesday (9 April).

marketNews.title: Mineral and Coal Royalty Increase Effective Early April
marketNews.content: Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said the increase in the mineral and coal (minerba) royalty rate will take effect in the second week of April 2025. Previously, the Director-General of the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, Tri Winarno, said last month that the royalty increase would follow the proposal presented in the public consultation on 8 March 2025.

marketNews.title: Trump Issues Executive Orders to Support U.S. Coal Industry
marketNews.content: U.S. President Donald Trump signed four executive orders on Tuesday (8 April) to boost the coal industry. The orders use emergency powers to allow several aging coal-fired power plants that are about to retire to continue operating in order to meet rising U.S. electricity demand driven by data-center, AI and electric-vehicle growth. The orders also direct federal agencies to identify coal resources on federal lands, remove mining barriers and prioritize leasing of coal mines on U.S. federal land.

marketNews.title: TBS Energi Utama Secures SGD 300 Million Credit Facility
marketNews.content: TBS Energi Utama, through its subsidiary Sembcorp Environment Pte. Ltd., obtained a term facility commitment of SGD 270 million and a revolving facility commitment of SGD 30 million from DBS Ltd. The facilities are intended to support the implementation and development of the company’s business plan.

marketNews.title: Petrosea Signs IDR 16 Trillion Nickel Services Contract
marketNews.content: Petrosea announced that it has signed a ten-year mining services contract worth IDR 16 trillion for the Bahodopi Block owned by Vale Indonesia (INCO). The contract was previously announced by INCO in January 2025.

marketNews.title: Indonesia’s 3Q 2025 Fiscal Update
marketNews.content: The Indonesian government’s budget deficit for the first three months of 2025 reached IDR 104.2 trillion, or 0.43% of GDP, compared with a 0.04% surplus in March 2024; the 2025 target is a 2.53% deficit. State revenue fell 16.8% YoY to IDR 516.1 trillion (17.2% of the 2025 target). State spending rose 1.4% YoY to IDR 620.3 trillion (17.1% of target). The primary balance fell to IDR 17.5 trillion (versus a surplus of IDR 122.1 trillion in March 2024; the 2025 target is a deficit of IDR 63.3 trillion). Budget financing reached IDR 250 trillion, 40.6% of the 2025 target (versus IDR 83.97 trillion in March 2024).

tickerNews.title: ADRO Announces Buyback Up to IDR 4 Trillion
tickerNews.content: Alamri Resources Indonesia announced a buy-back of up to approximately 926.8 million shares (3.01% of the company) with a total allocation of up to IDR 4 trillion. The buy-back will be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders’ meeting on 15 May 2025 and will be carried out over a 12-month period starting 16 May 2025.

tickerNews.title: ITMG Declares Final Dividend of US$153 Million
tickerNews.content: Indo-Tambangraya Megah shareholders approved a final dividend of US$153 million (IDR 2 245 per share) for fiscal year 2024, representing a final dividend yield of 9.9% as of 9 April 2025.

tickerNews.title: MIDI – SSSG +12.46% YoY in 1Q 2025
tickerNews.content: Midi Utama Indonesia reported same-store sales growth (SSSG) of +12.46% YoY in 1Q 2025 versus +13.67% YoY in 1Q 2024 and +9.13% YoY in 4Q 2024, beating the 2025 target of mid-single-digit growth. The company opened 34 new stores in 1Q 2025, equal to 17% of the 2025 target of 200 new stores, bringing the total Alfamidi store count to 2,469 at the end of 1Q 2025. The company also signed a divestiture agreement for its 70% stake in operator Lawson – PT Lancar Wiguna Sejahtera for an estimated IDR 200.5 billion, with completion expected by June 2025. The proceeds will be used for working-capital and capital expenditure.

tickerNews.content: Nippon Indosari Corpindo announced a dividend of IDR 450 billion (79.44 rupiah per share) payable on the regular market on 16 April 2025, with a record-date of 16 April and payment on 28 April 2025. Based on the closing price of IDR 910 per share on 9 April 2025, the implied dividend yield is approximately 8.7%.
